intro: Fabera hispida, commonly known as the roughleaf fabera, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring upright stems that are covered in stiff, bristly hairs. The leaves are lance-shaped, with a rough texture and often have a bluish-gray hue due to dense pubescence. Its small, white or pale pink flowers bloom in clusters during the summer months. The plant is often found in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky soils.
